awd_titl_txt: Probing the Milky Way Disk with Massive Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
Galaxies live and die by their star formation.  Galaxies, like our Milky Way, are rich in interstellar gas and dust clouds.  Gravity causes some interstellar clouds to collapse and form stars.  The largest, brightest, hottest, and most massive stars that form are called "OB stars."  OB stars are seen at their birthplaces because in their short lifetimes they do not have time to move very far from the collapsing interstellar clouds from which they formed.  The light from these OB stars is energetic enough to create "HII Regions."  HII regions are hot bubbles of fully ionized gas that surround their parent OB stars.  OB star formation and the HII regions that go with it are mostly confined to the spiral arms of galaxies.  HII regions are tracers of Galactic spiral structure.

Collaborations with Haystack Observatory and Green Bank Observatory (GBO) will bring the excitement of radio astronomy to Boston University undergraduates and provide mentors at the Physics Inspiring the Next Generation (PING) Summer Camp for 9th grade girls and boys held at Green Bank.  PING is a collaboration between GBO and the National Society of Black Physicists.

The OB star chemical abundances indicate the present state of the interstellar gas and reveal the elemental enrichment caused by the nuclear processing of many stellar generations.  They thus provide unique and important tracers of billions of years of Galactic chemical evolution (GCE).  The Southern HII Region Discovery Survey (SHRDS) will use the Australian Telescope Compact Array to find hundreds of heretofore unknown HII regions.  The SHRDS extends the successful Green Bank Telescope and Arecibo HRDS projects to the Southern sky; nearly half of the Milky Way disk cannot be observed from the Northern Hemisphere.  The SHRDS will improve the Galactic HII region census in the largest unexplored part of the Milky Way disk where the location of the spiral arms and the galactic bar is especially uncertain.  It will give the first complete map of where massive stars are forming in the entire Milky Way disk.  This map will allow a detailed analysis of the overall structure of OB-star formation sites in the Milky Way and how the physical properties of HII regions change across the disk.

New Galactic HII regions are discovered by detecting radio recombination line (RRL) radiation from candidate HII region targets. These targets are identified by comparing infrared and radio continuum images from existing surveys of the sky.  Comparing far-IR and radio continuum survey data leads to a list of some 2,000 candidate HII regions in the Galaxy.  RRL spectroscopic confirmation is needed to prove that a candidate is an H II region and to give its velocity.  The recombination lines give kinematic distances and electron temperatures for the nebulae.  Together, these allow derivation of the properties of the ionizing stars and the heavy element abundances, the metallicities, of the HII region gas.  A Galactic scale map of HII region metallicities can inform both GCE and the merger history of the Milky Way.  This project will achieve an areal density of sources, distributed throughout the Galactic disk, that can show local zones of metal enrichment (or depletion).  This would provide evidence for mergers, thus adding a new tool for the study of Galactic archaeology.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Galaxies like our Milky Way are rich in interstellar gas and dust clouds. Gravity causes some interstellar clouds to collapse and form stars. The largest, brightest, hottest and most massive stars that form are called "OB stars". The light from these OB stars is energetic enough to create "HII Regions". HII regions are hot bubbles of fully ionized gas that surround their parent OB stars.

At the core of an OB star an immensely powerful nuclear reactor fuses together atomically light elements (such as hydrogen and helium) into heavier elements. This fusion produces the energy that powers the star. When it reaches the end of its life, an OB star becomes a supernova.  The entire star detonates in a massive explosion that disperses these fused elements into the interstellar medium (ISM). Eventually, they may coalesce into new stars and planets.  The existence of life on Earth depended on supernovae. Every iron atom in our blood, for example, was formed deep inside an OB star.

OB star formation and the HII regions that these stars produce are confined to the spiral arms of galaxies.  OB stars are seen at their birthplaces, because in their short lifetimes they do not have time to move very far from where they formed. HII regions are the archetypical tracers of galactic spiral structure. Their chemical abundances indicate the present elemental composition of the interstellar gas and reveal the elemental enrichment caused by the nuclear processing of many stellar generations. They provide unique and important tracers of billions of years of Galactic chemical evolution.

A complete census of the Milky Way population of HII regions that includes their location in the Galaxy as well as the physical properties of the nebulae would produce the first complete map of where massive stars are forming in the entire Milky Way disc. A Galactic scale map of HII region locations and their elemental abundances could help solve key outstanding problems in our understanding of Galactic structure and Galactic chemical evolution.

Unfortunately, prior to our HII region discovery surveys, the census of Galactic HII regions was vastly incomplete. Using radio telescopes in Green Bank, West Virginia, Arecibo, Puerto Rico, and Narrabri, Australia, we have now completed HII region discovery surveys of the Northern and Southern sky that have almost tripled the number of known HII regions in the Milky Way.  New Galactic HII regions are discovered by detecting radio recombination line (RRL) radiation from candidate HII region targets. These targets, identified by comparing infrared and radio images from existing surveys of the sky, provide a list of candidate HII regions in the Galaxy.  Detecting RRL emission confirms that a target is actually an HII region.  We found RRL emission from ~90% of observed targets.  Most recently, we completed our Southern Hemisphere HII Region Discovery Survey and found over 500 previously unknown HII regions, leading to a current census total of over 2,500 Milky Way nebulae.

We now are exploiting this census with a research agenda that includes both follow up observations as well as writing a series of papers. Already published are papers that:  (1) Derive the Galactic HII Region Luminosity Function; (2) Discuss azimuthal structure in the elemental abundance distribution across the Galactic disk; (3) Derive the position of the Galactic plane using HII regions;  (4) Analyze the effects of ionizing radiation leaking from HII regions; (5) Detect RRL emission from the galaxies M51 and NGC628; and (6) Discover a new population of Galactic HII regions with large velocity gradients.

Our HII region census motivated us to study the Galactic distribution of ionized gas that is NOT associated with HII regions. We used the Green Bank Telescope to conduct the Galactic Diffuse Ionized Gas Survery which informed a series of papers on this major component of the ISM.

BROAD IMPACT

Students at all levels -- undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral -- were key members of our team. The collaboration produced 3 PhDs and every undergraduate collaborator went on to graduate school in Astronomy.

With FUTURUM staff (www.futurumcareers.com) we crafted the "Aiming For The Stars" brochure.  A major goal of Futurum is to "Offer teenagers and young adults - regardless of their gender, race or background - the knowledge and confidence to study science..."  FUTURUM has a significant web presence in the U.S., Canada, United Kingdom, Ireland, Australia, Europe, and New Zealand.
 
A collaboration with Green Bank Observatory (GBO), the Physics Inspiring the Next Generation (PING) Summer Camp for 9th grade girls and boys, brought the excitement of radio astronomy to a cohort of minority students.  PING is a collaboration between the GBO and the National Society of Black Physicists.
